questions.text:
A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 5-day history of abdominal pain that is sharp and intermittent. The pain is accompanied by episodes of nausea and vomiting, especially after consuming fatty meals. Medical history is significant for obesity, and he denies any use of alcohol or tobacco. Vital signs on presentation reveal:


Temperature
38.5°C (101.3°F)


Blood pressure
130/85 mm Hg


Heart rate
90/min


Respiratory rate
26/min


The patient appears ill. Physical examination reveals:

Mildly distended abdomen
Active bowel sounds
Guarding and rebound tenderness
Abdominal tenderness, most prominent in the right upper quadrant (RUQ)
Abrupt inspiratory pause upon deep palpation of the RUQ

Further examination of this patient is most likely to show an anterior Chapman reflex point at which of the following locations?

choices.text: 6th intercostal space on the right
8th intercostal space on the right
10th intercostal space near the costochondral junction bilaterally
6th intercostal space on the left
Tip of 12th rib on the right

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The Chapman points that correspond to the liver and gallbladder are located at the 5th– 7th ICS on the right (anterior location) and the right intertransverse spaces between T5 and T7, midway between the spinous and transverse processes (posterior location).

See “Gastrointestinal Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

B) INCORRECT:

The 7th–8th ICS on the right is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the pancreas. Conditions affecting the pancreas, such as acute pancreatitis, may manifest with abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In addition, abdominal tenderness, distention, and guarding may be seen on examination. However, acute pancreatitis typically manifests with severe constant epigastric pain that radiates toward the back, signs of shock (e.g., hypotension, oliguria), and, rarely, skin changes (e.g., Cullen sign, Grey Turner sign).

C) INCORRECT:

The 10th ICS near the costochondral junction bilaterally is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the ileum. Conditions affecting the ileum, such as Crohn disease, may manifest with low-grade fever and abdominal pain, but the primary symptom of Crohn disease is chronic diarrhea, and pain is typically located in the right lower quadrant. Other symptoms include weight loss, fatigue, a palpable abdominal mass, and extraintestinal symptoms (e.g., enteropathic arthritis).

D) INCORRECT:

The 6th ICS on the left is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the stomach. Conditions affecting the stomach, such as peptic ulcer disease (PUD), may manifest with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain that increases shortly after eating. However, PUD typically manifests with burning epigastric pain, gastrointestinal reflux, and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

The tip of the 12th rib on the right is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the appendix. Conditions affecting the appendix, such as acute appendicitis, may manifest with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and guarding and rebound tenderness. However, appendicitis typically manifests with migrating abdominal pain, a negative Murphy sign, and tenderness and guarding most prominent in the right lower quadrant.
questions.hint: Fever, RUQ pain, and a positive Murphy sign are consistent with acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 3 days of increased urinary frequency and pain with urination. She has no previous history of these symptoms. Medical history is unremarkable and her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. She states she is sexually active with three partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Upon questioning, she reports that she always urinates and cleans herself after sexual intercourse. She drinks 2–3 liters of fluid daily. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. Examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows a WBC count of 30/hpf (reference range: 0–5/hpf) and gram-positive cocci; a urine pregnancy test is negative. Results of a urine culture are pending. In which location is a tender gangliform nodule associated with this patient's condition most likely to be found?

choices.text: Inner thigh area
One inch lateral and one inch superior to the umbilicus
Periumbilical area
Medial border of the obturator foramen
Superior pubic ramus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gangliform nodule on the inner thigh area is consistent with the anterior Chapman point corresponding to the vagina. Infectious vulvovaginitis may result from a sexually transmitted infection, for which multiple sexual partners and unprotected sexual intercourse are risk factors. It may also manifest with dysuria, but usually manifests with (possibly malodorous) vaginal discharge, a burning sensation, pruritus, and dyspareunia.

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the vagina is located at the posterior superior iliac spine.

B) INCORRECT:

A gangliform nodule located one inch lateral and one inch superior to the umbilicus is consistent with the anterior Chapman point corresponding to the kidney. Pyelonephritis may manifest with symptoms of cystitis and urinalysis findings of pyuria and bacteria, but characteristic findings are fever, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and costovertebral angle tenderness.

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the kidney is located at the L1 transverse process.

C) CORRECT:

A tender gangliform nodule located in the periumbilical area is consistent with the anterior Chapman point corresponding to the bladder, which may occur in individuals with cystitis. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the bladder is located at the L2 transverse process.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

D) INCORRECT:

A gangliform nodule on the medial border of the obturator foramen is consistent with the anterior Chapman point corresponding to the uterus. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) affects the uterus and may result from a sexually transmitted infection, for which multiple sexual partners and unprotected sexual intercourse are risk factors. Additionally, PID may manifest with lower abdominal pain, dysuria, and urinary frequency. However, characteristic symptoms of PID are fever, nausea, vomiting, menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, and abnormal vaginal discharge. Physical examination findings of cervical motion tenderness and adnexal/uterine tenderness are also expected.

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the uterus is located at the L5 transverse process.

E) INCORRECT:

A gangliform nodule on the superior pubic ramus is consistent with the anterior Chapman point corresponding to the urethra. Urethritis often accompanies cystitis and may manifest with dysuria. It may also result from a sexually transmitted infection, for which multiple sexual partners and unprotected sexual intercourse are risk factors. However, other expected symptoms in urethritis are burning or itching of the urethral meatus and urethral discharge.

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the urethra is located at the L3 transverse process.
questions.hint: The combination of urinary frequency, dysuria, suprapubic tenderness, and urinalysis findings of pyuria and gram-positive cocci (e.g., Staphylococcus saprophyticus) suggests cystitis.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of vomiting and severe abdominal pain for the past 12 hours. The pain has progressively worsened, is accompanied by occasional episodes of diarrhea, and worsens with movement. The patient has not eaten since yesterday due to nausea. She denies any trauma. Medical history is unremarkable and she is otherwise healthy. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
38.6°C (101.4°F)


Blood pressure
105/67 mm Hg


Heart rate
102/min


Respiratory rate
18/min


Oxygen saturation
98% on room air


The patient appears uncomfortable. Heart and lung sounds are normal. Abdominal examination reveals exquisite tenderness to palpation and rebound tenderness of the right lower quadrant. Hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,900/mm3, and platelet count is 340,000/mm3. Urine dipstick testing is negative for nitrites and leukocyte esterase. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf and no RBCs. Where would an anterior Chapman reflex point most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: At the upper 1/5 of the right lateral thigh
At the lower 1/5 of the right lateral thigh
At the upper 1/5 of the left lateral thigh
At the 6th intercostal space on the right
At the 9th intercostal space near the costochondral junction on the right
At the tip of the 12th rib on the right

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the cecum is located at the upper 1/5 of the right lateral thigh. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the cecum is located between the L2 and L4 transverse processes.

B) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the hepatic flexure is located at the upper 1/5 of the right lateral thigh. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the hepatic flexure is located between the L2 and L4 transverse processes.

C) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the sigmoid colon is located at the upper 1/5 of the left lateral thigh. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the sigmoid colon is located between the L2 and L4 transverse processes.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the liver and gallbladder is located at the 6th intercostal space on the right. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the gallbladder is located between the T5 and T7 transverse processes on the right.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the jejunum is located at the 9th intercostal space near the costochondral junction. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the jejunum is located between the T9 and T10 transverse processes.

F) CORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the appendix is located at the tip of the 12th rib on the right. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the appendix is located at the T11 transverse process on the right.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations
questions.hint: This patient's right lower quadrant tenderness, nausea, fever, and leukocytosis should raise concern for acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of alternating constipation and diarrhea. She reports occasional blood on the toilet paper and a recent unintentional weight loss of 4.5 kg (10 lb). Medical history and family history are unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor and mild lower left abdominal tenderness. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy reveals an exophytic mass in the sigmoid colon. What is the most likely location of a Chapman reflex point associated with this patient's condition?

choices.text: Upper part of the right lateral thigh
Lower part of left lateral thigh
Lower part of right lateral thigh
Proximal inner thighs
Upper part of left lateral thigh

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The upper part of the right lateral thigh is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the cecum, not the sigmoid colon.

B) INCORRECT:

The lower part of the left lateral thigh is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the distal transverse colon at the splenic flexure, not the sigmoid colon.

C) INCORRECT:

The lower part of the right lateral thigh is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the proximal transverse colon at the hepatic flexure, not the sigmoid colon.

D) INCORRECT:

The proximal inner thighs on the lesser trochanter are the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the rectum, not the sigmoid colon. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the rectum is located at level S2 of the sacrum, near the lower end of the sacroiliac articulation.

E) CORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the sigmoid colon is located on the upper part of the left lateral thigh. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the colon is located in the triangular area between the transverse process of L2, the iliac crest, and the transverse process of L4.

See “Gastrointestinal Chapman points” table.
questions.hint: This patient's changes in bowel habits, hematochezia, and findings on colonoscopy indicate colorectal cancer that is located in the sigmoid colon. As a general rule, the anterior Chapman points of the colon can be located by splitting the anterior view of the transverse colon in the middle and flipping each side onto the thighs along the iliotibial band (i.e., flip rule).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower chest pain for the past hour. The pain radiates to the back, is associated with nausea, and worsens with food intake. He has had two episodes of nonbloody vomiting since the pain started. Medical history reveals hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks five to six beers per day. His medications include enalapril and metformin. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
38.5°C (101.3°F)


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Pulse
110/min


Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with epigastric tenderness and guarding but no rebound; bowel sounds are decreased. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies reveal a hematocrit level of 48%, leukocyte count of 13,000/mm3, and serum lipase level of 880 U/L. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. A tender gangliform nodule associated with this patient's current condition is most likely to be palpated

choices.text: between the spinous and transverse processes of T5 and T7 on the left
at the 6th intercostal space on the right
at the 7th intercostal space on the right
between the spinous and transverse processes of T7 and T8 on the left
at the 8th intercostal space bilaterally

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The space between the spinous and transverse processes of T5 and T7 on the left is the location of the posterior Chapman point that corresponds to the stomach. Conditions that affect the stomach, such as perforated gastric ulcers, may manifest with fever and abdominal pain, but dyspepsia is also expected. The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the stomach is located at the 6th intercostal space on the left.

B) INCORRECT:

The 6th intercostal space on the right is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the gallbladder. Conditions that affect the gallbladder, such as cholecystitis, may manifest with fever and abdominal pain, but the pain is usually in the right upper quadrant and may be referred to the right scapula. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the gallbladder is located at the right intertransverse spaces between T5 and T7, midway between the spinous and transverse processes.

C) CORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the pancreas is located at the 7th intercostal space on the right. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the pancreas is located at the right intertransverse space between T7 and T8, midway between the spinous and transverse processes.

See “Gastrointestinal Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

D) INCORRECT:

The space between the spinous and transverse processes of T7 and T8 on the left is the location of the posterior Chapman point that corresponds to the spleen. Conditions that affect the spleen, such as splenic infarction, may manifest with fever and abdominal pain, but the pain is usually in the left upper quadrant and may be referred to the shoulder. The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the spleen is located at the costochondral junction of ribs 7 and 8 on the left.

E) INCORRECT:

The 8th intercostal space near the costochondral junction is the location of the anterior Chapman point that corresponds to the duodenum. Conditions that affect the duodenum, such as perforated duodenal ulcers, may manifest with fever and abdominal pain, but dyspepsia and relief of pain with food intake are also expected. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the duodenum is located at the intertransverse space between T8 and T9, midway between the spinous and transverse processes.
questions.hint: Epigastric pain radiating to the back, vomiting, tachycardia, elevated temperature, and highly elevated lipase levels indicate acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of upper abdominal pain and intermittent nausea for the past 3 months. During this period she has also felt uncomfortable after meals and has vomited occasionally. Medical history reveals longstanding type 1 diabetes mellitus, diabetic nephropathy, and generalized anxiety disorder. Current medications include insulin, ramipril, and escitalopram. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, a distended abdomen, and mild epigastric tenderness. Structural examination reveals a Chapman reflex point at the 6th intercostal space on the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presenting symptoms?

choices.text: Chronic pancreatitis
Delayed gastric emptying
Increased gastric acidity
Increased lower esophageal sphincter tone
Dysfunction of the gastroesophageal junction
Chronic cholecystitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis can manifest with upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. However, the Chapman points associated with pancreatic dysfunction are located at the 7th intercostal space on the right (anterior Chapman point) and the right intertransverse space between T7 and T8 (posterior Chapman point). Patients with chronic pancreatitis would also present with severe epigastric pain radiating toward the back, which this patient does not have.

B) CORRECT:

Upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting in a patient with longstanding type 1 diabetes mellitus suggest diabetic gastroparesis, which is a disorder of stomach motility that causes delayed gastric emptying. The Chapman points associated with the stomach are located anteriorly at the 5th and 6th intercostal spaces on the left and posteriorly at T5–T7 intertransverse spaces. The Chapman point associated with stomach motility tends to appear at the 6th intercostal space while the Chapman point associated with stomach acidity tends to appear at the 5th intercostal space.

See “Gastrointestinal Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

C) INCORRECT:

Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), which is typically caused by increased gastric acidity, can manifest with upper abdominal pain, dyspepsia, nausea, and vomiting. The anterior Chapman point associated with stomach acidity tends to appear at the 5th intercostal space on the left. Additionally, patients with PUD typically present with features of acid reflux (e.g., retrosternal burning pain), and in some cases, signs of gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., anemia, melena), which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone, as seen in achalasia, typically manifests with dysphagia to both solids and liquids and retrosternal pain, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, the Chapman points associated with the esophagus are located at the 2nd intercostal space proximal to the sternum (anterior Chapman point) and T2 midway between the spinous and transverse processes (posterior Chapman point).

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can be caused by dysfunction of the gastroesophageal junction, can manifest with upper abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and nausea. The Chapman points associated with the esophagus are located at the 2nd intercostal space proximal to the sternum (anterior Chapman point) and T2 midway between the spinous and transverse processes (posterior Chapman point). Additionally, patients with GERD typically present with retrosternal burning pain and regurgitation, which this patient does not have.

F) INCORRECT:

Cholecystitis can manifest with upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. However, the Chapman points associated with gallbladder dysfunction are located at the 6th intercostal space on the right (anterior Chapman point) and at the right intertransverse spaces between T5 and T7 (posterior Chapman point). Additionally, patients with cholecystitis typically present with pain in the right upper quadrant that may radiate to the right scapula.
questions.hint: Chapman reflex points are somatic manifestations of an underlying visceral dysfunction. They typically manifest as round, smooth, and tender gangliform nodules that are approximately 2–3 mm in diameter.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The symptoms began suddenly after having intercourse with her partner four hours ago. The patient denies any fever, diarrhea, vaginal bleeding, or discharge. Menarche was at the age of 13 years and her last menstrual period was four weeks ago. Her only medication is an oral combination contraceptive. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
37.5°C (99.5°F)


Heart rate
100/min


Respirations
22/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg


Abdominal examination reveals severe right lower quadrant tenderness with rebound and guarding. Pelvic examination reveals right adnexal tenderness. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9000/mm3, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A Chapman reflex point associated with this patient's condition is located at the

choices.text: tip of the 12th rib
intertransverse space between T10 and T11
intertransverse space between T7 and T8
5th intercostal space
transverse process of L2

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An anterior Chapman point located at the tip of the 12th rib on the right is associated with the appendix. Conditions affecting the appendix (e.g., appendicitis) may manifest with abdominal pain, low-grade fever, nausea, vomiting, and severe right lower quadrant tenderness with rebound and guarding. However, patients typically also present with initial periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant and anorexia. Additionally, right adnexal tenderness would not be present.

B) CORRECT:

The Chapman points associated with conditions affecting the ovaries (e.g., ovarian torsion) are located at the intertransverse spaces between T9–11, midway between spinous and transverse processes (posterior Chapman point) and at the superior aspect of the pubic symphysis (anterior Chapman point).

See the “Genitourinary Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Posterior Chapman point locations

*Anterior vagina/clitoris Chapman point is shown on the posterior side.

C) INCORRECT:

A posterior Chapman point at the intertransverse space between T7 and T8 on the right is associated with the pancreas. A posterior Chapman point at the intertransverse space between T7 and T8 on the left is associated with the spleen.

D) INCORRECT:

An anterior Chapman point located at the 5th intercostal space on the right is associated with the liver. An anterior Chapman point located at the 5th intercostal space on the left is associated with the stomach.

E) INCORRECT:

A posterior Chapman point at the L2 transverse process is associated with the bladder. Bladder conditions (e.g., cystitis, urinary retention) often manifest with symptoms like dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain, and possibly hematuria, none of which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset localized adnexal tenderness following intercourse or physical activity is typical for ovarian torsion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of severe right flank pain radiating to the lower abdomen, nausea, and vomiting. The pain is colicky in nature and he describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. His medical history is remarkable for ulcerative colitis which is well-controlled with mesalamine. Physical examination reveals right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine dipstick testing results are positive for red blood cells. Renal ultrasonography shows right-sided hydronephrosis. The anterior Chapman reflex point that is associated with this patient's current condition is located

choices.text: at the lesser trochanter of the femur
at the umbilicus
one inch lateral and superior to the umbilicus
at the superior aspect of the pubic symphysis
at the lateral thigh

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lesser trochanter of the femur is the location of the anterior Chapman reflex point corresponding to the rectum. While this patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, his condition is well-controlled with mesalamine and so a positive Chapman reflex point would not be expected for this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

The umbilicus is the location of the anterior Chapman reflex point corresponding to the bladder, not the kidneys.

C) CORRECT:

The anterior Chapman reflex point corresponding to the kidneys is located one inch lateral and one inch superior to the umbilicus. The posterior Chapman reflex point corresponding to the kidneys is located between the spinous and transverse process of T12 and L1.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

D) INCORRECT:

The superior aspect of the pubic symphysis is the location of the anterior Chapman reflex point corresponding to the testes, ovaries, and urethra, not the kidneys.

E) INCORRECT:

The lateral thigh is the location of the anterior Chapman reflex point corresponding to the prostate, not the kidneys.
questions.hint: Colicky flank pain radiating to the lower abdomen, hydronephrosis, nausea, and hematuria indicate nephrolithiasis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to the office with a 4-day history of headache and thick nasal discharge. She had a sore throat and nasal congestion the week before that had initially improved. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Physical examination reveals purulent nasal drainage and tenderness to percussion over the maxillary sinuses. The nasal turbinates are erythematous and mildly swollen. Lungs are clear to auscultation. A Chapman reflex point is most likely present at which of the following locations?

choices.text: First rib near the clavicle
T2 between the spinous and transverse processes
Third intercostal space near the sternocostal junction
Second intercostal space near the sternocostal junction
T4 between the spinous and transverse processes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The Chapman points associated with conditions affecting the sinuses (e.g., sinusitis) are located at the first or second rib near the clavicle (anterior Chapman point) and the C2 level halfway between the spinous and transverse processes (posterior Chapman point).

See the “HEENT Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

B) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman point located at the T2 intertransverse space between the spinous and transverse processes is associated with conditions affecting the bronchi, esophagus, thyroid, and heart, not the sinuses. Conditions affecting the bronchi (e.g., bronchitis) often manifest with a runny nose, headache, and malaise. However, patients with bronchial conditions also present with other findings such as persistent cough, chest pain, and rhonchi or wheezing during auscultation, none of which is seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point located at the third intercostal space is associated with the upper lungs. Conditions affecting the lungs (e.g., pneumonia) manifest with cough, chest pain, and crackles or decreased breath sounds during auscultation, none of which is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point located at the second intercostal space is associated with conditions affecting the bronchi, esophagus, thyroid, and heart, not the sinuses. Conditions affecting the bronchi (e.g., bronchitis) can manifest with a runny nose, headache, and malaise. However, patients with bronchial conditions also present with other findings such as persistent cough, chest pain, and rhonchi or wheezing during auscultation, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman points located at the T3–T4 and T4–T5 intertransverse spaces between the spinous and transverse processes are associated with the upper and lower lungs, respectively. Conditions affecting the lungs (e.g., pneumonia) manifest with cough, chest pain, and crackles or decreased breath sounds during auscultation, none of which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a fever, headache, and purulent nasal discharge that was preceded by a sore throat and nasal congestion the week before. Her presentation is consistent with acute bacterial sinusitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of a burning sensation in her chest. The pain occurs almost daily, becomes severe when she eats spicy foods or drinks coffee, and often wakes her up at night. She has not had any weight loss during this period. She reports relief with over-the-counter antacids. Past medical history reveals hypertension. She smokes cigarettes and has a 20-pack-year history. She denies alcohol use. Physical examination is most likely to reveal a Chapman reflex point at which of the following locations?

choices.text: 7th intercostal space on the right
Between the spinous and transverse process of T2
8th intercostal space
Between the spinous and transverse processes of T6 and T7 on the right
Between the spinous and transverse processes of T2 and T3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point located at the 7th intercostal space on the right is associated with the pancreas. Conditions affecting the pancreas (e.g., acute pancreatitis) typically manifest with epigastric pain that may radiate to the back, nausea, vomiting, and fever, rather than retrosternal burning pain. The posterior Chapman point associated with the pancreas is located at the right T7–T8 intertransverse space.

B) CORRECT:

The Chapman points associated with conditions affecting the esophagus (e.g., GERD) are located between the spinous and transverse process of T2 (posterior Chapman point) and at the 2nd intercostal space near the sternum (anterior Chapman point).

See the “Gastrointestinal Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Posterior Chapman point locations

*Anterior vagina/clitoris Chapman point is shown on the posterior side.

C) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point located at the 8th intercostal space is associated with the duodenum. Conditions affecting the duodenum, such as duodenal ulcers, may manifest with burning pain that is relieved by antacids. However, patients with duodenal ulcers typically present with epigastric pain that improves with food intake. The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the duodenum is located at the intertransverse space between T8 and T9.

D) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman point located between the spinous and transverse processes of T6 and T7 on the right is associated with the gallbladder. Conditions affecting the gallbladder (e.g., cholecystitis) typically manifest with right upper quadrant pain that may radiate to the scapula, fever, and a positive Murphy sign on examination. The anterior Chapman point associated with the gallbladder is located at the 6th intercostal space on the right.

E) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman point located between the transverse and spinous processes of T2 and T3 is associated with the heart. Conditions affecting the heart (e.g., myocardial infarction, perimyocarditis) can manifest with retrosternal chest pain. However, burning pain that is exacerbated by food intake and relieved by antacids makes a cardiac etiology unlikely. The anterior Chapman point associated with the heart is located at the 2nd intercostal space.
questions.hint: The patient's heartburn, exacerbated by spicy foods, coffee, and lying down, and relieved with antacids is consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing generalized fatigue for 1 month. He reports mild upper abdominal discomfort and a 5.4-kg (12-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. Past medical history reveals hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. As an adolescent, he sustained a pelvic fracture that required a blood transfusion and surgery following a motor vehicle collision. His family history is unremarkable. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use any other substances. His current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly and palmar erythema. Laboratory studies reveal:


Hemoglobin
15.0 g/dL


Platelet count
80,000/mm3


Hemoglobin A1C

6.3%


Serum



_ Glucose
113 mg/dL


_ Total bilirubin
1.8 mg/dL


_ AST
40 U/L


_ ALT
44 U/L


A Chapman reflex point at which of the following locations is most likely to be palpated on further examination of this patient?

choices.text: Anterior pubic bone
Right intertransverse space between T7 and T8
5th intercostal space on the right
Left proximal iliotibial band
Between the spinous and transverse processes of T2
Between the posterior superior iliac spine and the transverse process of L5

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the testes is located on the anterior pubic bone. Although testicular cancer can manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss), a painless testicular nodule or swelling would also be expected. The posterior Chapman points corresponding to the testes are located at the intertransverse spaces between the transverse and spinous processes of T9–T11.

B) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the pancreas is located at the intertransverse space between the transverse and spinous processes of T7 and T8 on the right. Although pancreatic cancer can manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss) and upper abdominal discomfort, it also manifests with belt-shaped epigastric pain that typically radiates to the back. The anterior Chapman point corresponding to the pancreas is located at the 7th intercostal space on the right.

C) CORRECT:

The anterior Chapman points corresponding to the liver and gallbladder are located at the 5th–7th intercostal spaces on the right. The posterior Chapman points corresponding to the liver are located at the intertransverse spaces between the transverse and spinous processes of T5–T7 on the right.

D) INCORRECT:

The anterior Chapman points corresponding to the sigmoid colon are located along the left proximal iliotibial band. Although colon cancer can manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss), additional symptoms, such as changes in bowel habits, would also be expected. The posterior Chapman points corresponding to the sigmoid colon are located bilaterally in the triangular area between the transverse process of L2, the iliac crest, and the transverse process of L4.

E) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the esophagus and bronchi is located between the spinous and transverse processes of T2. Although esophageal carcinoma can manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss), typical symptoms such as dysphagia and anemia (due to chronic blood loss) would also be expected. The anterior Chapman points corresponding to the esophagus and bronchi are located at the 2nd intercostal space at the sternocostal junction.

F) INCORRECT:

The posterior Chapman point corresponding to the prostate is located between the posterior superior iliac spine and transverse process of L5. Although prostate cancer can manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss), it also typically manifests with lower urinary tract symptoms. The anterior Chapman points corresponding to the prostate are located on the lateral femur.
questions.hint: A blood transfusion before 1992 is a risk factor for hepatitis C. If left untreated, progression to chronic hepatitis C is common. Patients with chronic hepatitis C are often asymptomatic but may present with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., fatigue and weight loss) after gradual progression to cirrhosis. Splenomegaly and palmar erythema are also associated with cirrhosis. Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 150,000/mm3) is often a sensitive marker of cirrhosis; aminotransferase levels may be normal even in advanced cirrhosis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents with a 2-day history of high fever, headache, and neck stiffness. Medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
39.2°C (102.6°F)


Blood pressure
75/40 mm Hg


Heart rate
120/min


Respiratory rate
35/min


The patient appears ill. Physical examination reveals:

Drowsiness and irritability
Involuntary flexion of the knees and hips upon forced neck flexion
Nonblanching, petechial rash on trunk and legs

Further examination of this patient is most likely to show an anterior Chapman point at which of the following locations?

choices.text: 1 inch lateral and 2 inches superior to the umbilicus
5th and 6th intercostal spaces on the right
Tip of the 12th rib on the right
7th and 8th intercostal spaces on the right
Periumbilical area

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The anterior Chapman point associated with conditions affecting the adrenal gland (e.g., WFS) is located 1 inch lateral and 2 inches superior to the umbilicus. The posterior Chapman point associated with conditions affecting the adrenal gland is located at the intertransverse space between T11 and T12, midway between the spinous and transverse processes.

See “Endocrine Chapman points” table.
Image Description:

Anterior Chapman point locations

B) INCORRECT:

The Chapman points located at the 5th and 6th intercostal spaces on the right and at the right intertransverse spaces between T5 and T7, midway between the spinous and transverse processes, are associated with the liver. Conditions affecting the liver, such as pyogenic liver abscesses, may manifest with malaise, fever, signs of shock (tachycardia, hypotension), and altered consciousness. However, pyogenic liver abscesses typically manifest with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly. Furthermore, this patient's age, rash, lack of risk factors, and signs of meningeal irritation (e.g., neck stiffness, positive Brudzinski sign) make another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

The Chapman points located at the tip of the 12th rib on the right and at the right intertransverse space between T11 and T12, midway between the tips of the transverse processes, are associated with the appendix. Acute appendicitis complicated by a perforated appendix may manifest with high fever, signs of shock (tachycardia, hypotension), and altered consciousness. However, appendicitis typically manifests with migrating abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and guarding and rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Moreover, this patient's nonblanching petechial rash on his trunk and legs together with signs of meningeal irritation (e.g., neck stiffness, positive Brudzinski sign) make another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

The Chapman points located at the 7th and 8th intercostal space on the right and at the right intertransverse space between T7 and T8, midway between the spinous and transverse processes, are associated with the pancreas. Acute pancreatitis may manifest with fever, signs of shock (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension), altered level of consciousness, and skin changes. However, pancreatitis typically manifests with severe epigastric pain that radiates toward the back, abdominal tenderness, and guarding. Furthermore, this patient's age, rash, and signs of meningeal irritation (e.g., neck stiffness, positive Brudzinski sign) make another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

The Chapman points located at the periumbilical area and at the L2 transverse process are associated with the bladder. Pediatric urinary tract infections (UTIs) complicated by urosepsis may manifest with fever, irritability, signs of shock (tachycardia, hypotension), and altered consciousness. However, UTIs in children typically manifest with urinary frequency, dysuria, suprapubic and/or flank pain, malodorous urine, and new-onset urinary incontinence. Moreover, this patient's nonblanching petechial rash on his trunk and legs together with signs of meningeal irritation (e.g., neck stiffness, positive Brudzinski sign) make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Fever, headache, and signs of meningeal irritation (e.g., neck stiffness, positive Brudzinski sign) in combination with a nonblanching petechial rash suggest meningitis with Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (WFS). WFS is commonly caused by adrenal hemorrhage, resulting in acute primary insufficiency of the adrenal gland.
